metadata.sermon_title: Mine Eyes Have Seen the Glory
metadata.sermon_start_end: A good friend of mine is rector of a church in the Massachusetts Berkshires. She tells a story about her husband and his Sunday school class. Her husband is a physics professor at Williams College. He was teaching a class on the Transfiguration to some twelve-to thirteen-year-olds. [...] Yet even as the preacher stands before you bent and crippled by sin like all the rest of humanity, the message is that the light of redemption has dawned upon us all in the journey of the Son of God through death into life. He dies and he shines for you. AMEN.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails Dekker's first thesis by using four distinct passages rather than a single pericope. It functions as a thematic speech on 'glory' and 'faith' rather than an exposition of a specific text. It misses the 'unique point' of a single passage by harmonizing multiple motifs.
quotes: On this particular Sunday I was struck by the force of the challenge they brought.
Three of the four contain the same motif; the Psalm, the Old Testament lesson, and the Gospel all speak of a cloud.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Select one text (e.g., Matthew 17) and isolate what it says about God that cannot be found in the Exodus or Psalm passages. Stop treating the Bible as a collection of supporting themes.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: Exegesis is superficial. While the preacher notes the 'revealing and concealing' nature of the cloud, there is no rigorous engagement with the Hebrew or Greek context, nor the specific theological history of Israel beyond general imagery.
quotes: The images are a little confusing, aren’t they? First there’s a cloud, then there’s a fire.
In the Old Testament, appearances of God always cause fear.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Move beyond describing images to explaining the specific covenantal or historical necessity of the Transfiguration in Matthew's specific theological framework.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is concrete regarding the 'intellectual shame' of faith and the reality of suffering (Guatemala massacre). However, it often veers into generalities about 'contemporary Americans' and 'intellectuals' rather than the specific congregation.
quotes: In many circles today, it takes courage to be forthright about Christian faith.
One thinks particularly of the torments inflicted upon young children by adults... butchered in Guatemala.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Connect the 'devouring fire' of God's holiness more directly to the specific ethical or spiritual life of the Richmond congregation, rather than global or academic abstractions.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon follows a 'block' structure: anecdote, then textual survey, then contemporary reflection. The hearer is not consistently 'drawn into the text' as a single movement of revelation.
quotes: Let us turn to the Biblical passages for the Sunday of the Transfiguration.
The fourth reading two Sundays ago was the New Testament letter to the Philippians.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Avoid the 'tour guide' approach to multiple texts. Start within the tension of the text itself so that the application is the exposition.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The category of 'misery' is strongly present, particularly in the discussion of God's absence and human suffering. Redemption is correctly placed outside the self, in the 'Word made flesh'.
quotes: This agonizing problem of the absence of God... 'How long will you hide yourself, O Lord?'
Man has no life in himself, it is Christ who is his life. [Implicit in: 'the light of redemption has dawned upon us all']
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Ensure the 'gratitude' (sanctification/response) is more than just 'not being ashamed' but a concrete movement of the Spirit in the believer's life.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The 'two ways' are largely absent. While the preacher mentions the 'scorn of intellectuals,' the ultimate consequence of being 'lost' (temporal or eternal) is not addressed with the gravity Dekker demands.
quotes: It takes courage to be forthright about Christian faith.
The pressure to conform to a worldly standard.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: The preacher must address the reality that rejecting the 'terrible name' of God leads to destruction, not just social embarrassment.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is clearly the telos. The sermon correctly identifies that without the 'fearful power' of God in Christ, there is no real salvation. The doctrine of the two natures is present in the 'Word made flesh' and 'human flesh' of Jesus.
quotes: The divinity was there from the beginning... but it was concealed under the human flesh.
The very glory of God shines in the face of Jesus of Nazareth.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Make the connection between Christ's divinity and the 'devouring fire' of Exodus more explicit to avoid a sentimentalized Christology.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 18 minutes, the sermon falls just short of Dekker's 20-minute minimum. The use of four texts prevents the 'breadth' needed for true 'depth' in any single one.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Increase the duration by deepening the exegesis of one specific text rather than summarizing four.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon functions more as a thematic meditation on the 'Glory of God' across several lectionary readings than a sermon in the Dekkerian sense. It lacks the formal rigor of focusing on a single Bible passage and fails to address the 'two ways' with sufficient gravity. However, it succeeds in maintaining a high Christological focus and does not shy away from the 'misery' of God's apparent absence.
strengths: Strong Christological telos that emphasizes the divinity of Christ.
Adequate handling of human misery and the 'hiddenness' of God in the face of suffering.
Rejection of a 'wishy-washy' god in favor of the biblical 'fear of the Lord'.
weaknesses: Fragmentation caused by using four different Bible passages, preventing specific exegesis.
Insufficient duration and breadth according to the 20-minute rule.
Lack of the 'two ways'—the seriousness of being lost is replaced by the fear of intellectual embarrassment.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is an adequate religious address, but it is not a 'sermon' according to Dekker's strict formal definition. By failing to ground the proclamation in the unique, non-reproducible point of one specific text, it remains a speech about general biblical themes.
